bibl.title: Letter from Emilie Lawrence Reed to Ralph Rohrer Whittaker, [1932]

div1.p: Emilie Lawrence Reed thanks Whittaker for the sentiments expressed in his address "Unsung Heroes," and inquires if he knows the location of a church window dedicated to Christ, Florence Nightingale, and Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Emilie Lawrence Reed to Ralph Rohrer Whittaker, [1932]
div1.p:
Reply of June praise-worthy
oration, on “Unsung Heroes”
has been sent to me by
a kind friend & so
pleased am I wish justit
continued that I feel
urged to write to you,
thanking you for the
selection of your theme
& complementing you
on your earnest &
beautifullaudatory sentiments.
28 years ago nearly two years
after my husband's
death, a noted sci-
entist from abroad
took my hand &
pressing it warmly,
Said to me, “I am
proud indeed to hold
the hand of Walter Reeds
widow,- your & your
husband's fame will
grow & your children's
children will see
his fame much
greater than it is today,”
and his prophesy has
WASHINGTON, D.C.
come true. I am
the recipient of many
beautiful tributes -
none more touching
than the information
that came to me yesterday
A minister's wife from
Harrisburg told me
that she read this
story of a memorial
window being dedicated
somewhere, her memory
fail to recall where
it was of stained
glass, dedicated to the world's
the three greatest
humanitarians.

Christ, Walter Reed,
& Florence Nightingale.
Their faces pictured
in the glass- I
would so love to find
out where the window
is placed, for I am
[?] that one of the
most wonderful of all
tributes.

Had I have known
of you while you were
at Mercersburgs. I
would have been so
pleased to have met
you-, Mrs gave
me your address.
Hoping to have that
pleasure sometime in
the future

closer.signed:
Emilie L. Reed
Mrs Walter Reed
